Nifty question. But I'm not a geologist and really don't know much about it. BUT I have passed the question along to a geologist that I know.
 
 However, I can tell you that lava will not form granite because it isn't the correct composition. Lava is a mafic (mineral rich, especially iron) igneous rock. It forms rock that is known as basalt and gabbro. The plates that form the ocean floors are basalt and gabbro. They average about 6 km in thickness. The continental crust is much thicker than the oceanic plates. It goes higher and it goes deeper. The continental plates average 30 to 35 km thick but extends down some 65 km under mountain ranges. Two layers can be distinguished although there is no distinct boundry between them. The lower layer is also mafic (basaltic) rock while the upper layer is called felsic rock, composed of granite (feldspars and quartz) and diorite (pyroxene, amphibole, and biotite). Basalt usually has a density < 3.0 grams per cubic cm. while ghe felsic rocks are less that 3.0 grams/cubic cm.
 
 If you remember that below the mantel the earth is molten. Essentially the crust is floating on the liquid inner earth. I'm sure that you know that less dense things float better than dense things. A long time ago the granite floated to the top. It is very old.
 
 So pointing to the mantle and claiming that granite can't form from it is a bit like pointing to a bottle of milk with the cream separated on top and claiming that God created the cream since it isn't forming any more.

Basically, there is an old 'problem' called the granite problem that refers space issues related to granite formation. Actually, in terms of the chemistry forming granite is no problem. Rhyolite is an extrusive form of granite. It is identical in chemistry and composition to a granite and has been observed to erupt and cool in our time. Granite cooled slowly and formed larger crystals, but no one can claim that you cannot 'get' a granite. Furthermore, we have good geochronologic evidence documenting the time it takes for granite to cool. I don't know what this guy is getting at, but perhaps he's confused two separate issues related to granite formation.

This answer to the question poses an interesting question at the bottom.
 
from a poster named Calzaer on another board:
 
 Granite is an intrusive, felsic igneous rock formed by relatively slow cooling and crystalization of magma. It's made of primarily k-spar and quartz, with a bit of muscovite mica, and smaller quantities of biotite mica and amphibole. It certainly takes a long time to crystalize, which is why it's intrusive rather than extrusive, but to say magma will *never* form into it again is a completely daft statement. It takes just as long to form granite now as it did back in the cenozoic. 
 
 Quoting from my textbook:
 
Partial melting is another process by which magmas of more than once composition can form. As rocks undergo partial melting, the early-formed (low-temperature) magma [the stuff that's close to being granite - Cal] may rise (due to convection) or otherwise separate from the solid portion of the rocks to produce a body of felsic magma [the stuff required for granite to form - Cal]. At higher temperatures, however, the remaining portions of the rocks may melt to produce a higher-temperature magma of intermediate composition. This is one way to explain how granitic magmas [magmas that produce granite - Cal] can evolve from a subducting mass of seafloor basalt

 In short, granite is being formed RIGHT NOW.
